revision.text:
[[File:Avhuey 05.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Typical armament for UH-1 gunship]] The United States military has developed a number of '''Helicopter Armament Subsystems''' since the early 1960s. These systems are used for offensive and defensive purposes and make use of a wide variety of weapon types including, but not limited to [[machine gun]]s, [[grenade launcher]]s, [[autocannon]], and [[rocket]]s. Various systems are still in use, though many have become obsolete.
==Introduction== The [[helicopter]] has added much to the exploitation of the modern battlefield, changing traditional war-fighting scenarios to the extent that entirely new strategies and tactics have been developed both to utilise and deny the capabilities of these aircraft. In the air, against land-based threats, and at sea, helicopters can be used in offensive, defensive and transportation capacities to react swiftly to the fluid tactical conditions modern combat imposes on the battlefield.
[[File:CSA-2005-05-05-102937.jpg|thumb|UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters equipped with [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] machine guns on the M144 Armament Subsystem near [[Najaf|Najaf, Iraq]] in May 2005]]
Although one of the first armies to experiment with helicopters, the [[United States Army]] was slow to fully explore the possibilities of [[armed helicopter]] [[gunship]]s. Experiments between the [[Korean War]] and US involvement in [[Vietnam War|South East Asia]] were small and fairly simple. Learning much from their experience of these conflicts, the US decided to look further into the idea of air mobile tactics, and subsequently armed helicopters, though an armed helicopter had been proposed and rejected in the early 1940s. By the time the UTTHCO (Utility Tactical Transport Helicopter Company) was deployed to [[Vietnam]] in 1962, the US had started experimenting more with the idea of arming helicopters both for defensive and offensive purposes.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 23.</ref> UTTHCO was an expeditionary unit, deployed to Vietnam to assist the [[South Vietnamese]] Army and to provide on the ground testing for new air mobile theory. Weapon systems used by UTTHCO were often crude and made from parts and weapons readily available in the field.
By 1965, the United States had deployed a truly Air Mobile unit, the 17th Cavalry, which began to use more standardized armament systems. Throughout US involvement in Vietnam the US Army, US Marine Corps, and US Air Force would develop and utilize a number of armament systems designed for a variety of helicopters, and would pave the way for more dedicated attack helicopters.
With the arrival of dedicated gunship helicopters such as the [[AH-1 Cobra]] (since 1967) and later the [[AH-64 Apache]], armament subsystems for non-specific types would begin to drop off, with mostly defensive armament packages remaining. Such armament packages, giving decidedly heavy armament to small or primarily transport helicopters, have become popular among second and third world countries who lack the funds for dedicated attack helicopters. Most of those systems bear some resemblance to the plethora of US systems that follow in this entry.

==Armament sub-systems for transport and utility Helicopters==
===[[UH-1 Iroquois]]===
* '''XM3, XM3E1/M3, and TLSS''' The M3, sometimes referred to as "Aerial Rocket Artillery" or ARA, consisted of two 2.75" [[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket|24-Tube rocket launchers]], one on either side of the aircraft, along with a Mk 8 sight. The launchers fired in pairs, one from each side to prevent the aircraft from becoming off balance. M3 systems were attached to the helicopter using Bell designed stores racks.<ref name="tri.army.mil">''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aaarmsys.htm U.S. ARMY HELICOPTER WEAPON SYSTEMS (Page 1 of 2)]. Access Date: 7 May 2007</ref><ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1">United States, 1969. p. B-1</ref> The only difference between the XM3 and XM3E1 was that the launch tubes on the E1 were 4" longer. The XM3E1 was standardized as the M3.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
A subvariant of the M3 system was developed in 1964 by the US Army Limited War Laboratory that allowed equipped helicopters to produce a protective smoke screen. Called the '''Troop Landing Smoke Screen''' (TLSS), the system used modified M3 launch racks to dispense [[United States hand grenades#M8.2C M83 and Model 308-1 White Smoke|M8 smoke grenades]].<ref>Squieler, 1966. p. 1</ref> This system was later tested using [[United States hand grenades#M6.2FA1.2C M7.2FA1.2FA2.2FA3 and M54|M6 and M7 riot control grenades]].<ref>United States, 1965. p. 2</ref>
* '''XM5/M5''' The XM5/M5 system consists of a nose turret for a single [[M75 grenade launcher|M75]] 40mm grenade launcher. The mount was fully flexible and controlled by the pilot via a hand controlled sight electronically linked to the turret. The system either provided 150 or 302 rounds of ammunition.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 25</ref>
'''NOTE:''' This system was also part of the armament kit for the ACH-47A discussed later in this article.<ref name="Drendel, 1974. p. 8">Drendel, 1974. p. 8</ref>
* '''M6 Series'''
[[File:M6 Schematic.jpg|thumb|M6 Armament Subsystem on the UH-1B/C]] The M6 system was one of the first systems to make use of the XM156/M156 universal mount, providing two [[M60 machine gun|M60C]] 7.62×51mm machine guns on either side of the helicopter.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 22</ref> This system would later be expanded upon, but initially gave the UH-1 increased firepower and an improved offensive system over the skid mounts originally used.
The various development stages of the M6 system mainly had to do with the "station" to which the M156 mount was attached. The position of the XM6 is not stated, but the XM6E2 was fitted to "station 69" (likely forward of the main cabin) and the XM6E3 was fitted to "station 136." Since the XM6E3 was standardized as the M6, "station 136" is assumed to be the aft of main cabin position that would become standard for M156 based systems.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
Some M6 systems were coupled the four guns with four [[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket#Common Mk 40 FFAR Launchers|MA-2/A]] 2.75" 2-Tube rocket launchers on each side of the aircraft, giving an even greater punch. This arrangement was later supplanted by the XM16/M16 system.
* '''XM9''' A variant of the XM6/M6 system, the XM9 substitutes the four [[M60 machine gun|M60C]] 7.62×51mm machine guns with two [[M75 grenade launcher|M75]] grenade launchers, one on either side of the aircraft.<ref name="tri.army.mil"/>
[[File:M22 Schematic.jpg|thumb|M22 Armament Subsystem technical schematic]]
* '''XM11, XM22/M22, and the Maxwell System'''
Both of these armament systems were designed to allow the UH-1 to fire the [[SS.11|AGM-22]] missile. Sources claim that the XM11 provided an XM70 sight and support racks for 6 missiles, three on each side of the aircraft. However, US Army FM 1-40 says that the XM11 designation was unassigned.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
The M22 was an improvement providing a more specific sight, the XM58, and using the XM156 universal mount. The M22 also provided for a total of 6 missiles, three on each side of the aircraft. It is important to note as well that the XM11 is associated with the standard SS.11 missiles (AGM-22A), while the XM22/M22 system was designed around the US upgraded AGM-22B missiles.<ref name="Mutza, 2004. p. 41">Mutza, 2004. p. 41</ref>
The Maxwell System was a hybrid system designed by Warrant Officer Robert Maxwell as a field modification. Maxwell's unit had been sent both the M3 and XM11 systems, and he noticed that often aircraft with the M3 system returned after only firing half or less than half of their total rocket load. By removing one or two banks of rockets (and reducing the total carried to 12 or 18 total rockets versus 24) and adding a single launching mount for an [[SS.11|AGM-22]] missile he effectively gave the aircraft both suppression and point attack capabilities.<ref name="Mutza, 2004. p. 41"/> The general lack of point targets in South East Asia meant that SS.11/AGM-22 missile saw very limited use in general.
[[File:M16 Schematic.jpg|thumb|M16 Armament Subsystem with XM157 rocket launcher]] * '''XM16/M16'''
The XM16/M16 system mated the previous M6 with either two [[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket#Common Mk 40 FFAR Launchers|M157]] or two [[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket#Common Mk 40 FFAR Launchers|M158]] 2.75" 7-Tube rocket launchers utilizing the M156 Universal Mount. Sighting was accomplished by using the M60 series reflex sight. The combined weight and aircraft limitations meant that only seven-tube launchers could be used.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 24</ref>
* '''XM17''' The XM17 utilized "Kellet pylons" to mount two [[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket#Common Mk 40 FFAR Launchers|XM159]] 2.75" rocket launchers, one on each side of the aircraft.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
* '''XM21/M21''' A further variation on what had essentially become a basic system, the XM21/M21 subsystem replaced the XM16/M16's four [[M60 machine gun|M60C]]s with two [[Minigun|M134]] 7.62×51mm Miniguns.<ref name="tri.army.mil"/><ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
[[File:TM-9-1005-262-13 68 1.jpg|thumb|M23 Armament Subsystem on the UH-1D]] * '''XM23/M23''' The M23 system provides a pintle mount at both main cabin doors for an [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62×51mm machine gun, with the weapon feeding from either a standard ammunition box or a larger purpose built box connected to the mount.<ref>Mesko, 1984. p. 53</ref> The M23 is specifically designed for long fuselage UH-1s (UH-1D/H/N).<ref name="tri.army.mil"/><ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
* '''XM26'''
With the development of the [[BGM-71 TOW]] missile Hughes had been given the contract to develop a launching system for the UH-1. By 1968 development had shifted over to development of a system for the AH-56 helicopter which was eventually canceled. The XM26 provided two 3-Tube launchers on either side of the aircraft, as well as, the necessary sighting equipment. While the XM26 was more of a test platform, the two prototypes were deployed operationally as an emergency measure in South Vietnam to counter the Easter Invasion in 1972.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 67</ref>
* '''XM29 and the Sagami Mount''' The XM29 was an experimental door pintle for the main cabin doors of short fuselage UH-1s (at the time the UH-1B/C), for an [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62×51mm machine gun. The problem with this system was that it could not be used in conjunction with external armament subsystems.<ref>United States, 1969. p. B-2</ref>
[[File:XM26 Drawing.jpg|thumb|Drawing of the XM26 Armament Subsystem on the UH-1B helicopter]] Far more common on such helicopters, including the later UH-1F/P/M specifically, was the Sagami Mount, a skeleton frame mount that swung out from a fixed position at the rear of the cabin. This mount was designed for the M60D, but in certain instances, primarily by the US Navy Seawolves, dual [[M60 machine gun|M60]]s, [[M2 Browning machine gun|M2HB]] machine guns or [[Minigun|M134]] Miniguns were fitted.
Sources debate the origin of the "Sagami" name, with it being attributed to the soldier responsible for its creation,<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 26</ref> as well as, to the name of the US facility on Okinawa where it was developed.<ref name="US Army TACOM-RI Page 2">''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aaarmsy2.htm U.S. ARMY HELICOPTER WEAPON SYSTEMS (Page 2 of 2)]. Access Date: 7 May 2007</ref>
* '''XM30''' An experimental system, the XM30 provided fully flexible mounts using the XM156/M156 universal mounts for two [[XM140 30mm Cannon|XM140]] 30mm cannons, with 600 rounds of ammunition per gun.<ref>Gervasi, 1984. p. 242</ref>
* '''XM31''' Another attempt to up the firepower from existing systems, the XM31 provided two [[Hispano-Suiza HS.404|M24A1]] 20mm cannons in pods fitted to XM156/M156 universal mounts each with 600 rounds of ammunition, and flexible in elevation only.<ref>Drendel, 1974. p. 12</ref>
[[File:Specs54.jpg|thumb|XM59 Armament Subsystem with the XM213 machine gun on the UH-1D helicopter]] * '''XM50''' XM50 is a designation for the combination of the XM5/M5 and the XM21/M21 armament subsystems, a common configuration used by US forces in South East Asia.<ref name="US Army TACOM-RI Page 2"/>
* '''M56''' A mine dispenser system for the UH-1H helicopter, the M56 is composed of two SUU-13D/A dispensers on the M156 Universal Mount, which is reinforced to handle the additional weight.<ref>United States, 1993. p. 11-1-8</ref>
* '''XM59/M59''' A variation on the M23, the XM59/M59 was modified to accept either an [[M2 Browning machine gun#XM213.2FM213.2C XM218.2C GAU-15.2FA.2C GAU-16.2FA.2C and GAU-18.2FA|XM213/M213]] .50 caliber machine gun or an [[XM175 Grenade Launcher|XM175]] 40mm grenade launcher in addition to being able to mount the [[M60 machine gun|M60]].<ref name="US Army TACOM-RI Page 2"/>
* '''XM93/XM93E1''' This armament subsystem provides door mounts for long fuselage UH-1s (UH-1D/H/N) for two [[Minigun|M134]] 7.62×51mm Miniguns. The USAF also used this system on their short fuselage UH-1F/P helicopters. These weapons are equipped with chutes connected to their ejection ports that directs spent cases and links away from the aircraft.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 59</ref>
The XM93E1 is a variation on the system that allows both guns to be trained forward and remotely fired by the pilot using the M60 series of reflex sights.
'''NOTE:''' The USAF was the primary user of this system and often combined it with two [[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket|7-Tube]] 2.75" rocket launchers of varying types on two independent support rack and pylon assemblies.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 52</ref>
* '''XM94''' A variant of the XM93, the XM94 substitutes the [[M129 grenade launcher|M129]] 40mm grenade launcher for one or both of the door mounted [[Minigun|M134]] 7.62×51mm Miniguns.<ref name="Gervasi, 1984. p. 243">Gervasi, 1984. p. 243</ref>
* '''XM156/M156''' Not technically an armament subsystem, the XM156/M156 universal mount provided mounting supports and racks for a number of systems used on the UH-1 series of helicopters.<ref name="US Army TACOM-RI Page 2"/>
* '''A/A49E-3''' Similar to the US Army XM93, this system type classified by the Air Force uses mounts similar to those used in the M23 system mounting two [[Minigun|M134]] 7.62×51mm Miniguns at each of the main cabin doors of the UH-1N helicopters.<ref>Gunston, 1988. p. 189</ref><ref name="A/Annx Equipment Listing">Parsch, Andreas. ''Designation-Systems.net'' 23 November 2006 [http://www.designation-systems.net/usmilav/asetds/eq-a.html A/Annx Equipment Listing]. Access Date: 30 May 2007</ref> This system is likely suitable for other long-fuselage UH-1 types.
* '''A/A49E-11''' Referred to as the ''Defensive Armament System'' or DAS, this system is composed of two mounts for [[M2 Browning machine gun#XM213.2FM213.2C XM218.2C GAU-15.2FA.2C GAU-16.2FA.2C and GAU-18.2FA|GAU-15/A and GAU-16/A]] .50 caliber machine guns or [[Minigun#Variants|GAU-17/A]] 7.62×51mm Miniguns, as well as, two BRU-20/A or BRU-21/A bomb racks for current [[Hydra 70|2.75" rocket]] launchers.<ref name="A/Annx Equipment Listing"/><ref>''Federation of American Scientists'' 23 April 2000 [http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ac/equip/bru-20.htm BRU-20/A, -21/A, -22/A and -23/A Bomb Ejector Racks] Access Date: 30 May 2007</ref> This system was also designed primarily for use with the UH-1N helicopter (and is in use with the [[United States Marine Corps|US Marine Corps]] as well in this capacity), but is likely suitable for other long-fuselage UH-1 types.
[[File:TK-2 TAT-101 Picture.jpg|thumb|Two UH-1E helicopters with TK-2 Armament Subsystems and TAT-101 turrets]] * '''TK-2''' A variant of the TK-1 for the CH-34/UH-34 helicopter, the TK-2 (Temporary Kit-2) was developed by the USMC for their UH-1E helicopter. The system provides the same four [[M60 machine gun|M60C]] 7.62×51mm machine guns as the TK-1, but adds two independent support rack and pylon assemblies to the system, for mounting an acceptable aircraft style armament. Typically these mounts were used for [[Fin-Folding Aerial Rocket|7-Tube]] 2.75" rocket launchers of varying types, but were also seen tested with [[U.S. aircraft gun pods|XM18/M18]] [[Minigun]] [[Gun pod|pods]] (USAF SUU-11/A).<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 47</ref>
* '''Emerson TAT-101''' Unique to USMC UH-1E helicopters between April 1967 and 1972 was the use of the Emerson Electric TAT-101 (Tactical Armament Turret-101) nose turret. The turret housed two M60 machine guns with 1000 rounds total, and had 100 degrees in azimuth left or right, plus 15 degrees of elevation and 45 degrees of depression.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 51</ref> The slew-rate on the turret was 45 degrees per second.<ref name="Gervasi, 1984. p. 240">Gervasi, 1984. p. 240</ref> Jamming and the need for maintenance led to the turret's front fairing being left off to assist ground crews in quickly dealing with any problems, and these reasons combined in the USMC decision to drop the turrets from inventory entirely at the end of 1972.<ref>Mutza, 2004. pp. 47, 49</ref>
* '''Emerson Mini-TAT''' Developed to a Canadian requirement for their [[Bell UH-1N Twin Huey]], the Mini-TAT replaced the M60s with a [[minigun]]. A number of these were loaned to the US Army for use during the famous [[J-CATCH]] experiments in the late 1970s.<ref>[http://usafhpa.org/20helisq/20hornetsnew/newpage/76to90missions.html "The 20 Special Operations Squadron The Green Hornets 1944–1994"]</ref>
===[[SH-3 Sea King#Variants|SH-3/HH-3A Sea King (Sikorsky S-61)]]===
* '''Emerson TAT-102C''' A version of the TAT-102 (Tactical Armament Turret-102) designed specifically for use on the HH-3A helicopter, the TAT-102C mounted a single [[Minigun|M134]] Minigun in a fully traversable turret (for specifics see the information for the TAT-102A in the [[U.S. Helicopter Armament Subsystems#AH-1 Cobra|AH-1 Cobra entry]]).<ref name="United States, 1974. p. A-39">United States, 1974. p. A-39</ref> Two such turrets were mounted on sponsons, one on each side of the aircraft. The complexity and questionable performance in the environment led to them being removed in favor of more conventional door mounted weaponry.<ref>Morgan, 1998. p. 35</ref>
===[[Sikorsky S-61R|CH-3E Sea King/HH-3E Jolly Green Giant (Sikorsky S-61R)]]===
[[File:H-3E Diagram 2 copy.jpg|thumb|Diagram of HH-3E w/ M60D machine guns fitted to the three stations]] * '''Defensive Armament''' The defensive armament system for the USAF's H-3E helicopters is described as standard to the HH-3E, and capable of being fitted as required to the CH-3E.<ref>United States, 1982. p. 4-81</ref> The basic system comprises three [[M60 machine gun|M60]] machine guns, one each at the forward door, the opposite emergency window, and the rear loading ramp. The forward two positions comprise [[pintle]] mounts on skate rails, while the rear loading ramp station comprises a pedestal mount on an armored floor plate. The floor plate slides on two tracks, forward and back, to and from its firing position at the edge of the ramp. Either the standard infantry M60 can be used, with standard 200-round ammunition boxes attached, or the [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]], feeding via flexible ammunition chutes from 750-round boxes fixed to the floor (or to the armored floor plate for the rear loading ramp position).<ref>United States, 1982. p. 4–83-5</ref>
===[[CH-21 Shawnee]]===
* '''XM153''' Described as a system of four forward firing [[M60 machine gun|M60]] machine guns similar to the later M6 series for the UH-1 helicopter. Not standardized.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
* '''Offensive Armament''' Experiments were done using CH-21s with both fixed forward [[M2 Browning machine gun|M2HB]] .50 caliber machine guns and forward firing rocket launchers. Neither system was standardized, but both paved the way for similar systems on later helicopter types.<ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 24 February 2006 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aahist.htm HISTORIC U.S. ARMY HELICOPTERS]. Access Date: 7 May 2007</ref>
* '''Defensive Armament''' UTTHCO deployed with a number of CH-21's, and experimented with field expedient bars mated to the cargo doors, fitted with [[M1919 Browning machine gun|M37C]] .30-06 machine guns and feed from boxes mounted on top of the weapon.<ref>Mesko, 1984. p. 8</ref>
'''NOTE:''' It would appear that similar mounts were fabricated for use with early UH-1s as well.<ref>Mutza, 2004. p. 21</ref>
===[[Sikorsky H-34|UH-34/CH-34]] Choctaw/Seahorse===
* '''XM4''' Described simply as a "[[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket|2.75-inch rocket]] launcher subsystem for the CH-34," there is no information as to how many rockets the XM4 was capable of launching.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
* '''XM6E1''' For more information on the M6 Series see the [[U.S. Helicopter Armament Subsystems#UH-1 Iroquois|UH-1 entry]] in this article. The XM6E1 was a variation of the XM6 for use with the CH-34 helicopter.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
[[File:TK-1 Picture.jpg|thumb|TK-1 Armament Subsystem on the UH-34D helicopter]] * '''TK-1'''
A USMC weapon system to provide H-34 helicopters with offensive armament, the TK-1 (Temporary Kit-1) featured two [[M60 machine gun|M60C]] 7.62×51mm machine guns, fixed forward on the right side of the aircraft, with ammunition fed out from boxes inside the aircraft. Also attached to these assemblies were two pylons, fitted with 19-shot [[Mk 4/Mk 40 Folding-Fin Aerial Rocket|2.75-inch rocket]] launchers. Aircraft equipped with the TK-1 were sometimes referred to as "Stingers."<ref>Fails, 1978. pp. 87–88</ref>
* '''Defensive Armament''' Both the US Army and the USMC developed pintle mounts for use in the main cargo door and opposite window, mounting a single infantry type [[M60 machine gun|M60]] 7.62×51mm machine gun (sometimes referred to as "M60A"), allowing the crew chief to fire the weapon while seated on the opposite side. The USMC tested mounting the heavier [[M2 Browning machine gun|M2]] machine gun, but found the vibration when firing to be detrimental to the aircraft.<ref>Lundh, 1998. p. 48</ref> In all the mounts were imperfect as they blocked easy entry and exit from the main cabin.
===[[CH-46 Sea Knight]]=== * '''Defensive Armament'''<ref name=3-22.4-CH46E>{{cite book|last=Office of the Chief of Naval Operations|first=Department of the Navy|title=CH-46E Naval Aviation Technical Information Product (NATIP)|year=2010|publisher=NAVAIR|location=Chapter 1}}</ref>
The CH-46E Sea Knight has the ability to mount the [[M2 Browning#XM213.2FM213.2C XM218.2C GAU-15.2FA.2C GAU-16.2FA.2C and GAU-18.2FA|XM-218]] .50 caliber heavy machine gun. On the left side of the helicopter it is mounted in the AO's (Aerial Observer) window just behind the copilots seat. On the right side it is mounted in the Gunner's window just behind the crew door. The aircraft is also set up to carry a RMWS (Ramp Mounted Weapon System) which holds the [[M240#M240E1 and M240D|M240D]] 7.62mm medium machine gun.
* '''XM-218''' The XM-218, 0.50 caliber aircraft machine gun is a belt-fed, recoil-operated, air-cooled, alternate-feed weapon fired from the [[closed bolt]] position. It is capable of firing at a rapid rate of 750-850 rounds per minute.
* '''M240D''' The M240D machine gun is a belt-fed, gas-operated, air-cooled, alternate-feed automatic weapon fired from the [[open bolt]] position. It has a rate of fire of 650-950 rounds per minute.
===[[CH-47 Chinook]] and [[CH-47 Chinook|ACH-47A]] "Guns-a-GoGo"===
* '''M24''' A defensive armament subsystem, the M24 provides a pintle mount for an [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62×51mm machine gun at either left or right front cargo doors on the CH-47. The system feeds from standard 200-round ammunition boxes attached to the weapon.<ref name="Gervasi, 1984. p. 243"/>
'''NOTE:''' The US Army phased out the [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] in favor of the [[M240 machine gun#M240E1 and M240D|M240D]] and subsequently [[M240 machine gun#M240E5.2FM240H|M240H]]. While the mount system designation remains the same, the mount itself has been extensively redesigned to accommodate the ammunition magazine and a bag for catching expended ammunition casings and ammunition links, as well as an improved roller on the pintle to prevent excessive and premature wear to the mount assembly.
* '''XM32''' A defensive armament subsystem, the XM32 provides pintle mounts for either [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62×51mm machine guns or [[M2 Browning machine gun|M2HB]] .50 caliber machine guns at both cargo door positions and at both rear emergency hatches of the CH-47 helicopter, with weapons feeding from standard ammunition boxes. This system was developed specifically for the ACH-47 helicopter.<ref name="Drendel, 1974. p. 8"/>
* '''XM33''' A defensive armament subsystem, the XM33 provides a mount for either an [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62×51mm or an [[M2 Browning machine gun|M2HB]] .50-caliber machine gun on the rear cargo ramp of the CH-47 helicopter. This system was developed specifically for the ACH-47 helicopter, with the weapon feeding from standard ammunition boxes.<ref name="Drendel, 1974. p. 8">Drendel, 1974. p. 8</ref>
* '''XM34''' An offensive armament subsystem developed for the ACH-47 helicopter, the XM34 provides two [[Hispano-Suiza HS.404|M24A1]] 20mm cannons with ammunition boxes on sponsons at the front of the aircraft fixed forward.<ref name="Drendel, 1974. p. 8"/>
'''NOTE:''' These sponsons were also fitted with aircraft-style hardpoints that allowed the mounting of [[Fin-Folding Aerial Rocket#Common Mk 40 FFAR Launchers|XM159B/XM159C]] 19-tube 2.75"-rocket launchers or [[U.S. aircraft gun pods|M18/M18A1]] 7.62×51mm gun pods.
* '''XM41/M41''' A defensive armament subsystem, the M41 provides a mount for an [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62×51mm machine gun on the rear cargo ramp of the CH-47 helicopter. The system feeds from standard 200-round ammunition boxes attached to the weapon.<ref name="Gervasi, 1984. p. 243"/>
'''NOTE:''' The US Army phased out the [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] in favor of the [[M240 machine gun#M240E1 and M240D|M240D]] and subsequently [[M240 machine gun#M240E5.2FM240H|M240H]], but it is unknown whether the necessity of a new cradle for the weapon (as with the M24 above) resulted in the system being redesignated. The mount is otherwise the same.
===[[CH-53 Sea Stallion]]/[[MH-53 Pave Low|HH-53/MH-53 Super Jolly/Pave Low]]/[[CH-53E Super Stallion|CH-53E Super Stallion/MH-53E Sea Dragon]]===
* '''Defensive Armament''' Defensive armament systems for the H-53 series as used by the US Navy have no known designation, but generally comprise pintle mounts at "personnel or cargo doors or windows of the aircraft."<ref name="United States, 2003. p. 3-1-1">United States, 2003. p. 3-1-1</ref> These mounts are usually equipped with either [[M2 Browning machine gun#XM213.2FM213.2C XM218.2C GAU-15.2FA.2C GAU-16.2FA.2C and GAU-18.2FA|GAU-15/A, GAU-16/A, or GAU-18/A]] .50 caliber, or [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62 mm machine guns.<ref name="United States, 2003. p. 3-1-2">United States, 2003. p. 3-1-2</ref> The .50 caliber weapons were later supplanted by the [[M2 Browning machine gun#GAU-21.2FA and M3P|GAU-21/A]] .50 caliber machine gun, which featured a higher rate of fire.
===[[UH-60 Black Hawk]]/[[SH-60 Seahawk|SH-60 Sea Hawk]]/[[HH-60 Jayhawk]]/[[HH-60 Pave Hawk|HH-60/MH-60 Pave Hawk]]===
* '''M139''' The [[Volcano mine system|M139 Volcano]] is a mine dispenser system composed of racks on both sides of the aircraft for up to 40 Canister, Mine, M87. Each canister contains 6 [[GATOR mine system|GATOR]] Anti-Tank mine and 1 GATOR Anti-Personnel Mine.<ref name="globalsecurity.org">United States Government. ''Global Security.org''. 27 April 2005. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/policy/army/fm/3-04-500/appg.htm TFM 3-04.500 Army Aviation Maintenance, Appendix G]. Access Date: 26 June 2007</ref><ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aaarmsy2.htm U.S. ARMY HELICOPTER WEAPON SYSTEMS (Page 2 of 2)]. Access Date: 26 June 2007</ref>
* '''M144''' The M144 is a defensive subsystem that provides mounts and cradles at the two windows between the pilot doors and the main cabin doors on the UH-60 series of helicopters, each mounting a single [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] 7.62×51mm machine gun.<ref name="US Army TACOM-RI Page 2"/>
'''NOTE:''' The US Army phased out the [[M60 machine gun#M60D|M60D]] in favor of the [[M240 machine gun#M240E1 and M240D|M240D]] and subsequently [[M240 machine gun#M240E5.2FM240H|M240H]], or [[M-134 Minigun]]s, but it is unknown whether the necessity of a new cradle for the weapon resulted in the system being redesignated. The mount is otherwise the same. The USAF equips its [[HH-60 Pave Hawk|HH-60/MH-60 Pave Hawk]] with one or two [[M2 Browning machine gun#XM213.2FM213.2C XM218.2C GAU-15.2FA.2C GAU-16.2FA.2C and GAU-18.2FA|GAU-15/A, GAU-16/A, or GAU-18/A]] .50 caliber machine guns, and or [[GAU-2]] series 7.62mm NATO [[Minigun]]s. Example; One .50 caliber MG in the floor, firing out of an open door and two 7.62mm NATO miniguns mounted in the door gunner positions.
* '''ESSS''' The External Stores Support System (ESSS) provides two stub wings each with two hard points primarily for external fuel tanks, but, it can also carry various weapon systems. When equipped with the Extended Range Fuel System (ERFS), the system can support two 870 L (230 gal) or 1,700 L (450 gal) external tanks. The system feeds into the main fuel tank and not the engines directly.<ref name="globalsecurity.org"/> The ESSS can also be fitted with a wide range of weapons including up to sixteen [[AGM-114 Hellfire]] missiles, [[Hydra 70|rockets]] and [[gun pod]]s, and other systems.<ref>Gunston and Spick, 1986. pp. 154–55</ref><ref>[http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=ADA196187&Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf Preliminary Airworthiness Evaluation of the UH-60A/ESSS with Hellfire Launcher Installed]</ref>
[[File:RAMICS Picture.jpg|thumb|Prototype RAMICS gun and mount on an MH-60S helicopter]]
* '''AN/AWS-2 RAMICS''' Still in development as of 2003, the Rapid Airborne Mine Clearance System (RAMICS) can be considered an armament subsystem (and one of the largest guns ever fitted to a helicopter), though its intended targets are strictly naval mines. Consisting of a single modified [[Bushmaster II|Mk 44 Mod 0]] 30mm cannon firing the Mk 248 Mod 1 Armor-Piercing Fin-Stabilized Discarding-Sabot Tracer (APFSDS-T) round, the RAMICS was intended to be mounted in the cabin of the MH-60S helicopter, and using its associated sensor package, target and neutralize mines at relatively shallow depths. The system is designed to provide a quick and effective mine clearance capability to complement existing methods and others under development for the Navy's Airborne Mine Countermeasures (AMCM) Program.<ref>Jenkins, Alan K. ''National Defense Industrial Association''. 27 March 2003. [http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/2003gun/jen.pdf The RAPID AIRBORNE MINE CLEARANCE SYSTEM (RAMICS) Approach to Entering Flight Test]. Access Date: 23 June 2007</ref><ref>Osborne, Tony [http://www.shephard.co.uk/news/rotorhub/euronaval-2010-a-big-gun-for-a-big-threat/7506/ Euronaval 2010: A big gun for a big threat] [[Shephard Group]], 25 October 2010</ref>
==Armament sub-systems for observation and other light helicopters==
===[[SH-2 Seasprite|HH-2C Seasprite]]===
* '''Emerson TAT-102K''' A version of the TAT-102 (Tactical Armament Turret-102) designed specifically for use on the HH-2C helicopter, the TAT-102K mounted a single [[Minigun|M134]] Minigun in a fully traversable turret (for specifics see the information for the TAT-102A in the [[U.S. Helicopter Armament Subsystems#AH-1 Cobra|AH-1 Cobra entry]]).<ref name="United States, 1974. p. A-39"/> A single such turret would mounted in the nose of the aircraft. The weight of the mount was not suitable for such a small helicopter and the turret was often removed.<ref>Morgan, 1998. p. 32</ref>
===[[OH-6 Cayuse]] (and [[MD 500 Defender]])===
* '''XM7''' The XM7 system provided twin [[M60 machine gun|M60]] machine guns (unknown type) on the OH-6 series of helicopters. It is unclear if both guns were mounted together or whether they were mounted one on each side of the aircraft. As of 1969 the system was listed with the comment "development suspended," likely in favor of the XM27.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/> This system was also tested on the [[Fairchild Hiller FH-1100|YOH-5A]] during August 1964.<ref name="United States, 1964. p. viii">United States, 1964. p. viii</ref>
* '''XM8''' The XM8 system provides a mount for one [[M129 grenade launcher|M129]] 40mm grenade launcher for either the OH-6 or OH-58 light observation helicopters. The system is provided with an XM70/E1 sight and 150 rounds of ammunition. The XM8's mount is interchangeable with the M27 system.<ref>Gunston, 1988. p. 201</ref>
This system could also be mounted on the [[OH-58 Kiowa]], and was tested on the YOH-5A during August 1964.<ref name="United States, 1964. p. viii"/>
[[File:XM27 Schematic.jpg|thumb|Schematic of the XM27 on the OH-6A helicopter]] * '''M27 Series'''
The M27 system provides a mount for one [[Minigun|M134]] 7.62×51mm machine gun (Minigun) for either the OH-6 or OH-58 light observation helicopters. The system is provided with an XM70/E1 sight and a MAU-56/A delinking feeder with 2000 rounds of ammunition.<ref>Jane's, 1986. pp. 453–54</ref> The system has no movement in azimuth, but has 10 degrees of elevation and 24 degrees of depression.<ref name="Gunston, 1988. p. 199">Gunston, 1988. p. 199</ref>
The initial XM27 featured a mount similar to a gunpod, which was quickly exchanged for a more aerodynamic fairing, as well as improvements to the ammunition stowage and other equipment on the XM27E1.<ref>United States, 1969. p. C-31-2</ref> The XM27E1 was standardized as the M27. The fairing was removed entirely because for ease of maintenance and to reduce weight on the M27E1. The M27's mount is interchangeable with the XM8 system.<ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aaarmsys.htm U.S. ARMY HELICOPTER WEAPON SYSTEMS (Page 1 of 2)]. Access Date: 24 June 2007</ref>
As with the XM8, this system can also be mounted on the OH-58 Kiowa.
* '''HGS-55''' Using a mount similar to that used on the XM8 and M27 series, the HGS-55 was developed by the [[McDonnell Douglas|McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company]] (formerly [[Hughes Helicopters]]) to use the [[Hughes EX 34 chain gun|EX 34 Mod 0]] 7.62×51mm [[chain gun]].<ref>Jane's, 1986. p. 454</ref> The weapon is supplied with a 2,000-round magazine, and the weapon fires between 550 and 700 rounds per minute.<ref name="Gunston, 1988. p. 199"/> This system was not adopted by the US military for use, and no export sales were known to have been made.
===[[H-13 Sioux|OH-13 Sioux]] and [[OH-23 Raven]]=== [[File:Xm1m37c.gif|thumb|XM1 on the OH-13]] * '''XM1/XM1E1''' In service between 1960 and 1972, the XM1 consisted of two [[.30-06 Springfield|.30-caliber]] [[M1919 Browning machine gun#M37|M37C]] machine guns mounted on the landing skids of either the OH-13 or OH-23 helicopter. These weapons were fixed forward, but flexible in elevation, with their ammunition (500 rounds per gun) stored externally. The XM1E1 was the product engineering design.<ref>Mutza, 1995. p. 32</ref>
'''NOTE:''' What would appear to have been a variant of the XM1 system was used by UTTHCO on their HU-1As (later [[UH-1]]A) for a short period.<ref>Mutza, 2004. pp. 3, 21</ref>
[[File:M2m60c.gif|thumb|M2 on the OH-13]] * '''M2''' The M2 system was a variation on the XM1, replacing the [[.30-06 Springfield|.30-caliber]] [[M1919 Browning machine gun#M37|M37C machine guns]] with [[7.62×51mm]] [[NATO]] [[M60 machine gun#M60C|M60C]] machine guns. The mounts were similar to the XM1, also providing flexible elevation, with 650 rounds per gun stored externally.<ref name="United States, 1969. p. B-1"/>
===[[OH-58 Kiowa|AH-58D/OH-58D Kiowa Warrior]]===
* '''Universal Weapons Pylon and Gun Pod''' The Universal Weapons Pylon is specific to the OH-58D Kiowa Warrior helicopter, and provides two support racks for various weapon systems. The racks, with stores mounted, may be folded 180 degrees upward for rapid loading into the C-130 transport aircraft, though the connecting umbilicals must be disconnected to prevent damage.<ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 7 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/kpuwp.htm UNIVERSAL WEAPONS PYLON]. Access Date: 26 June 2007</ref>
There are at least ten authorized armament configurations, which involve a mix of a system specific [[gun pod]] mounting the [[M2 Browning machine gun#AN.2FM2.2C M3.2C XM296.2FM296.2C and GAU-10.2FA|M296]] .50 caliber machine gun (left side only), the [[Hydra 70|M260]] 7-shot 2.75in/70mm Lightweight Launcher (LWL), the M279 2-rail [[AGM-114 Hellfire]] launcher, or a 2-shot [[FIM-92 Stinger|Air-to-Air Stinger (ATAS)]] launcher.<ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 7 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/kpdesc.htm OH-58D KIOWA WARRIOR ARMAMENT, EQUIPMENT DESCRIPTION]. Access Date: 26 June 2007</ref> The gun pod is fed from a semi-external magazine loaded with 500 rounds of linked ammunition.<ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 7 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/kpammofd.htm AMMUNITION FEED SYSTEM]. Access Date: 26 June 2007</ref>
===[[HH-65 Dolphin|MH-65C Dolphin]] and [[Agusta A109#Agusta A109|MH-68A Stingray]]===
* '''Airborne Use of Force (AUF) Package''' The [[United States Coast Guard|US Coast Guard]] has deployed the MH-68A to its newly created [[Helicopter Interdiction Tactical Squadron]] (HITRON), and it is the only helicopter in USCG inventory specifically tasked with the [[Airborne Use of Force]] (AUF) mission. These helicopters feature a defensive armament system composed of a single [[M240 machine gun#M240G|M240G]] mounted at the port cabin door, along with a [[Robar RC-50|Robar Arms RC-50]] rifle attached to the cabin via a bungee cord for disabling hostile light vessels.<ref>Neubecker, Lt. Craig. ''United States Coast Guard''. May 2003. [http://www.uscg.mil/history/webaircraft/AC_HITRON_History.html Helicopter Interdiction Tactical Squadron]. Access Date: 21 August 2007</ref> The kit is also capable of being used on the HH-65C aircraft. When so fitted the aircraft is designated MH-65C.
==Armament sub-systems for dedicated gunships== [[File:XM28 Schmatic.jpg|thumb|Schematic of the XM28, with XM129 grenade launcher on the right station and M134 machine gun on the left station, on the AH-1G helicopter]]
===[[AH-1 Cobra]]===
* '''M28 Series (Emerson TAT-141)'''
The standard fixed armament for the AH-1G, AH-1P (formerly referred to as AH-1S Production), AH-1Q, and initial AH-1S models, this turret unit is similar to the XM64 mentioned later in this section, but was capable of mounting two [[Minigun|M134]] Miniguns, two [[M129 grenade launcher|M129]] 40 mm grenade launchers, or one of each weapon. Miniguns fitted are capable of pre-set firing rates of either 2,000 or 4,000 RPM, while the turret itself has 114 degrees of motion left or right, 17.5 degrees of elevation and 50 degrees of depression<ref>Gunston, 1988. p. 188.</ref> (alternate sources describe 110 degrees in azimuth, 20 degrees of elevation and 50 degrees of depression for the M28E1 model specifically<ref name="Gervasi p241">Gervasi, 1984. p. 241.</ref>). Each Minigun is linked to 4,000 rounds of ammunition while each grenade launcher is fed from a 300-round magazine.<ref name="Gervasi p241"/>
The system is known to have four standard A variants, the M28/A1-A3. However, the actual specifics between variants is vague. From the available information suggests that specific variants were mated to specific iterations of the AH-1 helicopter. The initial XM28/M28 were fitted to the AH-1G, as were the M28E1/M28A1. The M28A1E1/M28A2 was fitted to the AH-1Q, while the M28A3 (no developmental variation known) was fitted to the AH-1P/S helicopter.<ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 7 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/cpm28.htm M28 Aircraft Armament Subsystems]. Access Date: 16 June 2007</ref><ref name="Viet_era_pg2-3">''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aahist2.htm Historic U.S. Army Helicopters, Vietnam Era Helicopters (Page 2 of 3)]. Access Date: 16 June 2007</ref> There is the possibility that the M28A2 could have been the first unit designed to work with the XM128/M128 Helmet Sight System (HSS) developed primarily for use with TOW armed AH-1s.<ref name="Viet_era_pg2-3"/>
* '''XM35/M35''' An armament subsystem providing a single [[M61 Vulcan#Applications|M195]] 20 mm cannon on the port inboard pylon of the AH-1G. 950 rounds of ammunition were stored in boxes faired to the side of the aircraft. The system was primarily pilot controlled, but featured dual controls to be either pilot or gunner controlled. For this purpose the pilot was provided with a M73 sight.<ref>Drendel, 1974. p. 35.</ref><ref>Gunston, 1988. p. 193.</ref><ref name="Gervasi_p242"/>
* ''' XM64 (Emerson TAT-102A)'''
[[File:TAT-102A Schematic.jpg|thumb|Schematic of the Emerson TAT-102A on the AH-1G helicopter]]
The TAT-102A (Tactical Armament Turret-102A) was the initial main armament for the AH-1G helicopter, though designed as an interim measure.<ref>Mutza 2002. p. 7.</ref> It is related to the TAT-101 mentioned in the UH-1 entry. The turret mounts a single [[Minigun|M134]] Minigun with 25 degrees of elevation, 90 degrees of depression, and 180 degrees of motion in azimuth, with a slew rate of 80 degrees per second.<ref>Gervasi, 1984. p. 240.</ref> The TAT-102A was designated XM64 by the US Army.<ref name="Heli_Weapon_pg2-2">''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aaarmsy2.htm U.S. ARMY HELICOPTER WEAPON SYSTEMS (Page 2 of 2)]. Access Date: 21 May 2007</ref>
* '''XM65/M65''' The Cobra Missile System is a functional development of the XM26 and the TOW missile system developed for the failed AH-56 helicopter. Originally designed for the AH-1Q and AH-1S Cobras, the AH-1F Modernized Cobra was also rebuilt to use the system. The original iteration of the system comprises launchers allowing for four [[BGM-71 TOW]] missiles per aircraft pylon to be carried, and a '''TSU''' or '''Telescopic Sight Unit''', to allow for targeting and guidance of the missile. The TSU has been upgraded with the '''LAAT (Laser-Augmented Airborne TOW)''', a day/night range finder, and '''C-NITE (Cobra-Night Imaging Thermal Equipment)''', a thermal imagine/FLIR system specifically for the AH-1S and AH-1F Cobra helicopters.<ref name="Heli_Weapon_pg2-2"/>
* '''M97 Series and A/A49E-7 (GE Universal Turret)''' The standard fixed armament system for the US Army's AH-1S Upgunned Cobra (eventually redesignated AH-1E Enhanced Cobra Armament System or ECAS) and the AH-1S Modernized Cobra (eventually redesignated the AH-1F), as well as, the US Marine Corps' AH-1J, AH-1T, AH-1W, and AH-1Z helicopters. The system was designed to fit either the [[M197 Gatling gun|M197]] 20 mm three barreled cannon or the [[XM188 30 mm Cannon|XM188]] 30 mm three barreled cannon. In practice the M197 was the standard fit and the XM188 was not adopted for service. The turret has 110 degrees of motion in azimuth, 21 degrees of elevation, and 50 degrees of depression, with a slew rate in azimuth of 80 degrees per second and in elevation and depression of 60 degrees per second.<ref name="Gervasi p241"/><ref>Gunston, 1988. p. 196.</ref>
As with the M28 series, the specifics between variants of the M97 are vague. Five Standard A models are known to exist, M97/A1-A4. Sources suggest that individual variants of the turret were specific to certain variants of the AH-1 as with the M28 series. The M97A1 (and possibly the M97) was fitted to the AH-1S Upgunned Cobra, the M97A2/A3 to the AH-1S Modernized Cobra (AH-1F), and the M97A4 to production AH-1Fs.<ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 7 October 2005. [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/cpm197.htm M97A4 Armament Subsystem M197 20 mm Automatic Cannon]. Access Date: 16 June 2007</ref> Other sources say that the M97A3 was refitted to AH-1E ECAS and the M97A2 was the initial armament for the AH-1S Modernized Cobra, agreeing that the M97A1 was the original fit to the AH-1S Upgunned Cobra.<ref>''Global Security.org''. 15 August 2006. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/ah-1s.htm AH-1S Cobra]. Access Date: 16 June 2007</ref> There is also the possibility that the differences have something to do with the associated equipment for the M197 cannon, including the use of the M89 or M89E1 delinking feeder.<ref>''Federation of American Scientists''. 23 April 2001. [http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ac/equip/m197.htm M197 20mm Automatic Gun]. Access Date: 16 June 2007</ref>
The M97 was also fitted to the AH-1J, but it is unclear if the AH-1T, AH-1W, and AH-1Z used variants of the M97 series. The subsystem used on the AH-1T and AH-1W has a designation in the USAF's Aeronautical and Support Equipment Type Designation System (ASETDS), A/A49E-7.<ref>Parsch, Andreas. ''Designation-Systems.net'' 23 November 2006 [http://www.designation-systems.net/usmilav/asetds/eq-a.html A/Annx Equipment Listing]. Access Date: 16 June 2007</ref> The turret in the system is also designated under the ASETDS system, as the GTU-1/A.<ref>Parsch, Andreas. ''Designation-Systems.net'' 4 September 2007 [http://www.designation-systems.net/usmilav/asetds/u-g.html#_GTU GAU/GAK to GUU - Equipment Listing]. Access Date: 12 September 2007</ref> How this system differs from its US Army counterparts is unknown. An amendment to the official Military Specification, MIL-F-85668(AS), put out by the United States Naval Air Systems Command on 15 November 1995, actually listed the "A/A49E-7(V4)" as inactive pending a new design, and listed the system as relevant only to the "AH-1T (TOW)."<ref>United States Government, 1995</ref><ref>United States Government, 1984</ref>
* '''XM120 (Emerson TAT-140)''' A competing universal turret design to the M97 put forward by Emerson Electric, the XM120 could be fitted with a number of weapons including the [[M60 machine gun|M60C]] 7.62×51mm machine gun, [[Minigun|M134]] Minigun, [[M197 Gatling gun|M197]] 20 mm three barreled cannon, [[XM188 30 mm Cannon|XM188]] 30 mm three barreled cannon, and was in fact tested with the [[XM140 30mm Cannon|XM140]] 30 mm cannon.<ref name="Gervasi, 1984. p. 240"/><ref>''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aaarmsy2.htm U.S. ARMY HELICOPTER WEAPON SYSTEMS (Page 2 of 2)]. Access Date: 16 June 2007</ref>
===[[AH-56 Cheyenne]]=== [[File:Xm52dwg.jpg|thumb|XM52 Armament Subsystem on the AH-56A helicopter]] [[File:Xm53dwg.jpg|thumb|XM53 Armament Subsystem on the AH-56A helicopter]]
* '''XM51''' A nose turret with one [[M129 grenade launcher|M129]] 40 mm grenade launcher with 300 rounds. In light of the failure of the AH-56 was proposed as a replacement for the M5 system on the UH-1 helicopter. Designed to be interchangeable with the XM53.<ref name="Gervasi_p242">Gervasi 1984. p. 242.</ref>
* '''XM52''' Belly turret with a single [[XM140 30mm Cannon|XM140]] 30 mm cannon. Use on other helicopters was also debated.<ref name="Gervasi_p242"/>
* '''XM53''' A nose turret with one [[Minigun#Design and variants|XM196]] 7.62×51mm machine gun. Also said to be suitable for the UH-1 series of helicopters. Designed to be interchangeable with the XM51.<ref name="Gervasi_p242"/>
===[[AH-64 Apache]]===
* '''M139 and Area Weapon Subsystem''' The only type classified subsystem for the AH-64 series, the M139 is composed of the '''Aerial Rocket Control System''' (giving the aircraft the ability to fire members of the [[Hydra 70|Hydra 70/Mk 66]] 2.75 in/70 mm rocket family), a dispenser interface (controlling the M130 chaff/flare dispenser, also used on the AH-1 helicopter), and the '''Area Weapon Subsystem'''.<ref name="ReferenceA">''US Army TACOM-RI''. 5 October 2005 [http://tri.army.mil/LC/CS/csa/aaarmsy2.htm U.S. ARMY HELICOPTER WEAPON SYSTEMS (Page 2 of 2)]. Access Date: 17 June 2007</ref>
The Area Weapon Subsystem is made up of a single [[M230 Chain Gun|M230]] 30 mm cannon, turret and assembly, ammunition feed, and other electronic components for the functioning of the system.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The unit is capable of 100 degrees of motion in azimuth left or right, 11 degrees of elevation and 60 degrees of depression, and feeds from an ammunition magazine with 1,200 rounds.<ref>Gunston, 1988. p. 201.</ref>
===[[RAH-66 Comanche]]===
* '''Turreted Gun System (TGS)''' The RAH-66 Comanche was intended to have a gun system designed jointly by Boeing and Sikorsky. The system was to use the XM301 lightweight gun, and fed linked ammunition from a 500-round storage drum. The turret itself had 120 degrees of movement in azimuth, with 15 degrees of elevation and 45 degrees of depression. The TGS was supposed to be ready for deployment with the Comanche helicopter during the FY04 period, but the cancellation of the Comanche ended further development of this system.<ref>Huang, Karl. ''National Defense Industrial Association''. 3 May 2000. [http://web.archive.org/web/20080625152636/http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/ammo/huang.pdf Comanche Turreted Gun System]. Access Date: 10 October 2007</ref>
